content.raw: I think the `apt-get update` should not be here. Also all the lines later on that do `apt-get install` should be preceded by `apt-get update` and followed by `apt-get clean` \(the same pattern as is already above\). Otherwise rebuilds of the image might be broken.
content.html: I think the apt-get update should not be here. Also all the lines later on that do apt-get install should be preceded by apt-get update and followed by apt-get clean (the same pattern as is already above). Otherwise rebuilds of the image might be broken.

content.raw: Thanks. I fixed both this file an the `cloudsim_sim/Dockerfile` in c8141ea.
content.html: Thanks. I fixed both this file an the cloudsim_sim/Dockerfile in c8141ea.

content.raw:
Here is how I tested the cloudsim docker images.

## Terminal 1: Build and run the cloudsim_sim docker image

This is the docker image that corresponds to the "Simulation Container" on: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture.

1. `./build.bash cloudsim_sim --no-cache`
2. `./run.bash cloudsim_sim cloudsim_sim.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1  robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG2`

## Terminal 2: Build and run the cloudsim_bridge docker image

This is the docker image that corresponds to the "Bridge Container" on: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture.

1. `./build.bash cloudsim_bridge --no-cache`
2. `./run.bash cloudsim_bridge robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1  robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG2`

## Terminal 3:  Run X1 controller

This is where a team would run their own controller for X1. In lieu of that, I ran from my catkin workspace:

```
roslaunch subt_example example_robot.launch name:=X1
```

## Terminal 4:  Run X2 controller

This is where a team would run their own controller for X2. In lieu of that, I ran from my catkin workspace:

```
roslaunch subt_example example_robot.launch name:=X2
```

## Terminal 5: Test!

1. Test the comms network.

    ```
rostopic pub /X2/comm std_msgs/String "X1"
    ```
This should cause output in Terminal 3 (X1 controller) similar to:

    ```
    [ INFO] [1563661130.260521094, 1.903000000]: CommClientCallback
    ```

2. Test movement by driving the X1 forward:

    ```
rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear:
  x: 2
  y: 0
  z: 0"
    ```
content.html:
Here is how I tested the cloudsim docker images.

Terminal 1: Build and run the cloudsim_sim docker image

This is the docker image that corresponds to the "Simulation Container" on: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture.

  1. ./build.bash cloudsim_sim --no-cache
  2. ./run.bash cloudsim_sim cloudsim_sim.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG2

Terminal 2: Build and run the cloudsim_bridge docker image

This is the docker image that corresponds to the "Bridge Container" on: #!/osrf/subt/wiki/cloudsim_architecture.

  1. ./build.bash cloudsim_bridge --no-cache
  2. ./run.bash cloudsim_bridge robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG1 robotName2:=X2 robotConfig2:=X2_SENSOR_CONFIG2

Terminal 3: Run X1 controller

This is where a team would run their own controller for X1. In lieu of that, I ran from my catkin workspace:

roslaunch subt_example example_robot.launch name:=X1

Terminal 4: Run X2 controller

This is where a team would run their own controller for X2. In lieu of that, I ran from my catkin workspace:

roslaunch subt_example example_robot.launch name:=X2

Terminal 5: Test!

  1. Test the comms network.

    rostopic pub /X2/comm std_msgs/String "X1" This should cause output in Terminal 3 (X1 controller) similar to:

    [ INFO] [1563661130.260521094, 1.903000000]: CommClientCallback

  2. Test movement by driving the X1 forward:

    rostopic pub /X1/cmd_vel geometry_msgs/Twist "linear: x: 2 y: 0 z: 0"
